intro: Quercus subcrispata, commonly known as the Mexican bristle oak, is a deciduous tree native to central Mexico. It is characterized by its small, acorn-like fruits and serrated leaves that are often hairy on the underside. The plant belongs to the Fagaceae family, which includes oaks, beeches, and chestnuts. It typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid climates. Its botanical features make it an important component of the local ecosystem and a subject of interest for botanists and conservationists.
